												Free if you have Half Life: Episode One. I completed it in about 4 hours last night on Hard so it's not a very time consuming game either. Was very entertaining, very difficult at times which I believe is a positive. Actionpacked to the max, always a firefight behind every corner. The map was amazing, a bit like The Silent Cartographer from Halo: Combat Evolved. Music in true Half Life-style, pumping beats to get your heart rate up. Puzzles and combat as in Half Life although more combat oriented, set in the same universe. Spawn system/level design is one of the best I've seen. There's a set number of enemies per "event" (like opening a door, there's a lot of these), meaning you can clear it out entirely and feel somewhat safe. But the "events" put spawns far away at times, making the enemies then run towards the sound of fire but only arrive after most things are dead, surprising you without feeling random and making the experience harder and more lifelike at the same time. Never coming at you alone, always from several angles. At times scaring me to screams, panicing against what seemed like impossible odds in the moment. Fast paced, fluid, brutal. Excellent. If you have Episode One and like combat more than running around looking at the view then you should play it. That's not to say it's not a beautiful game, it's probably the best looking game in the entire franchise... and it's a mod.

												*NOTICE* I just finished playing this mod and here is my final verdict.MINERVA: Metastasis, what may appear as a generic, fanmade Half-Life 2 mod on the outside actually appears more on the inside. I have played many Half-Life 2 mods and this one definetely goes on my list of one of the most interesting if not one of the best Half-Life 2 mods I have ever played. The mod is mysterious which really fits into the Half-Life universe, the story is told via text which may seem horrible on paper with many flaws, which it does don't get me wrong, but it gets the job done and in a way gives MINERVA its character.The level design in MINERVA is very similar to Half-Life 2's level design yet also has some variation with the mod being more maze-like than Half-Life 2's which in my honest opinion gives the mod more variation and gives an immersion factor to it. The mod is also surprisingly challenging compared to Half-Life 2 and I was playing on Normal difficulty! I mean its not rage inducing hard but the beginning levels do stir up a challenge with the mod throwing enemies at you in tight corridor-like locations. It the kind of hard difficulty which does test you, makes you think and makes you aware of your surroundings and makes you think of plans to take on the many Combine foot soldiers and aliens head crabs and zombies that you will encounter.There is a lot more to say about MINERVA, the design of the levels and the detail that the mod developer placed are truly amazing, the gameplay and pacing is spot on and the mod just truly feels interesting to play. Many things in MINERVA are also interesting with the themes of Greek Mythology being in the game with the Narrator telling you your mission objectives via text.The story in MINERVA like I said is mysterious with a lot of what is going on is confusing but atleast there's forums to explain whats going on. A lot with MINERVA also fits in with the Half-Life universe that I feel that someday Valve should incorporate into that next Half-Life game that we are all waiting for. When you get to a certain part involving a portal you'll see what I mean, not spoiling it that is.In the end MINERVA is a must play, it really makes you happy to play a good Half-Life 2 mod, its short yet sweet, and plus it makes you think more as to what Half-Life 3 could be.

												MINERVA is a beautiful, well paced mod for Half Life 2. Taking place on an island occupied by the combine, it features fantastic level design that rivals that of vanilla Half Life 2. The areas weave together in a very believable way and every area is shrouded by an air of mystery. Also noteworthy is the expert use of verticality. I often found I was able to use this to my advantage against the numerous, well placed enemies in MINERVA. Not only are the areas well designed, but each is also visibly distinct. Because of this, I never found myself lost for long. I even stopped once to admire the setting sun reflecting off the ocean's waves. The Story is engaging enough. It does a good job of adding to the mystery of the island, although it would have benefited from proper voice acting as it is sometimes difficult to read during intense gunfights. Over all, MINERVA provides some of the best Half Life 2 content I have experienced. Anyone with a copy of Half Life 2 owes it to themselves to give this a try.

												This mod requires ownership of Half-Life 2: Episode 1. This review also assumes you already own and have completed Half-Life 2 and its two episodes.Mod: Minerva: MetastasisFor the game: Half-Life 2Developer and publisher: Adam FosterReleased: 28 April, 2013Genre: First-Person Shooter with HorrorCanon status: Non-canonSetting: 15 October, 2009, an unnamed island, Baltic Sea, Europe, EarthSpoiler-free plot summary: You play as an unnamed renegade Combine soldier only referred to as Perseus. After arriving on an island controlled by the Combine, a mysterious member of the Resistance, only referred to as Minerva, guides you via on-screen messages on your quest to destroy the facility built beneath the island.Full review: Minerva is a short and mildly difficult mod for Half-Life 2: Episode 1. This mod is no doubt one of the best Half-Life mods ever created, and Valve must have thought so too because they ended up hiring Adam Foster to work with them!Another Half-Life 2 mod, more typical Half-Life 2 gameplay of running-and-gunning and solving a few puzzles. No new game mechanics are introduced like several other Half-Life mods; instead, this mod is based on level design. Being set in an underground facility beneath a small island, the levels in Minerva are very vertical. You'll find that most of the combat sequences require shooting at enemies above and/or below you, and that navigating can be very maze-like, especially in the final sequence, when the facility begins to self destruct and you have to run through the now ruined areas you previously went through.Dialogue with Minerva can be quite awkward; if you proceed through levels too quickly, her messages will overlap, so you can miss out on crucial information, like how to solve a puzzle, and because the text is bright orange, you won't be able to read her messages in bright areas or against brightly-colored surfaces.Do I recommend Minerva? Yes; it's higher in quality compared to other Half-Life mods, and it can entertain you for a couple of hours. If Half-Life 2 is a meal and its episodes are dessert, then this mod is a breath mint; small and sweet.

												Just finished my first playthrough of MINERVA: Metastasis. What an excellent, excellent mod. It is all the more impressive when you know it's been made by one guy, who went on to be hired by Valve.And no wonder: the level design is excellent. None of those frequent loading screens that plague Source games. In fact, I only remembering one loading screen in a 4-hour playthrough of massive proportions. It makes great use of space, compressing game areas, using verticality, sending you back and forth sometimes - never tediously.Another excellent bit is the pacing. This is a brutal fight from start to finish, with intermittent calm stretches. The rhythm is perfect. The modder manages to craft action sequences within HL2's trademark limited perspective. Unlike modern games where you feel like you are watching your character do all the cool stuff, here you get to do them yourself.At one point, you are stripped of all your weapons & ammo, and soon an avalanche of enemies is unleashed on you and you must scramble down foreign corridors, frantically searching for an armory, solving puzzles at lightning speed with your pursuers hot on your heels.Even though the game is linear, in true HL fashion, I often found myself stuck, only to finally go "of course!" notice and solve a mini-puzzle, and proceed to the next bit. It's refreshing to once again play a game that doesn't hold your hand - I can't help but be used to that by now, with modern games going out of their way to nudge you in the right direction at all times.So yes, breathtaking difficulty - of the thrilling kind, not the frustrating kind - and no hand holding. Although if you stay stuck for a long long time, there is a subtle and plot-appropriate hint system.The plot is very basic, but very intriguing. It doesn't get in the way, and it's not an afterthought by any means - but it leaves you with questions, and that's very cool.One last thing - the mod uses some HL2 musical tracks, but there's an additional musical score that's awesome, and I must acquire it.

												I dare say this is damn near a masterpiece. On more than one occasion, this phenomenal game is better than Half-Life 2 itself. The level design is some of the smartest I've ever played. 												TIME TO COMPLETE: 3.4 hoursMINERVA, or MINERVA: Metastasis are one and the same thing. Throughout the years I've heard people using both names and so I thought there was a sequel, but in truth it is not. This is the sole mod.I enjoyed it. From a well-delivered story to outstanding level design, MINERVA is packed with non-stop action. It contains what made Half-Life 2 great, or shall I say...Episode One? Now that I think about it each Half-Life game (aside from the first's expansions, mostly) has had its own, unique taste. Episode One, for example, had those creepy encounters and focus on Antilion/Zombie combat, but is at the same time hideous in pacing. You get the crowbar waaay later on. This is another story, but even with that said I'd have to compare MINERVA to Episode One. It does not have the same horrible pacing, but it has the same familiarity. Half of the game is Combine combat, the other is mixed. You can feel the same vibes present.I will not spoil the story more than I should, but the text-on-screen method of storytelling worked nicely, unlike most of the time you'd seen it fail. You are an ex-Combine soldier who's gone head-on into a Combine facility buried deep within an island. That's it for one, but it gets much more interesting along the way.Now the only significant thing that has bothered me (no bugs/glitches encountered, guess I was lucky) was that our protagonist still wears the HEV suit model from the original game. Like, yes, it is a hazard suit, but why the same look? Wouldn't it be a little more fitting to have some black jumpsuit with armor pieces strapped on? I considered this to be a little immersion-breaking, but to be honest it's not something that will bother you a lot. The constant tension in between will make sure of that.A great deal of work has been put into this map, and I'd like to congratulate the author. A must-try for Half-Life fans. Let's not even talk about the fact that it's free, but you still need to own Episode One. I suppose you do, innit?

												MINERVA was a modification that was thoroughly enjoyable to play. Crafted to the level of quality where one could have thought that it was one of Valve's creations. Nicely paced combat, well thought places for health and ammunition refills, and a nice challenge. The story was driven through an enigmatic narrator, which created a nice dynamic to the game. A gripping edge-of-the-seat experience, which I played through in one sitting. The only negative thing really, and this doesn't actually count as negative, was the relative shortness and the vagueness of information given about the elements of the story. But then again the vagueness sparks imagination in it's own way, and fits in the Valve's style of not revealing too much information. If you search for a new delve into the universe of Half-Life, look no further.

												Minerva is a two hour FPS set in the universe of HL2. It has probably the most beautiful maps and design I have seen in a source game or mod since playing through Shadgrimgrvy's Paranoia map series. It has decent sound design, and an overall above average story (that I'd rather not spoil). However, it simply is far too difficult to be fun. The majority of encounters in this mod consist of seemingly buffed enemies, with numerous units. Generally, you are armed with weapons that are inneffective, and twice in the story, you are forced to lose all of your weapons. These are followed by encounters that are frequently annoying or cause you to die more than you really should half to.In fact, the very ending of the game is the easiest encounter, which is strange considering that it's a battle with a gunship.Overall, the difficulty of this game is almost to the level of being heinous, and it never stops forcing you through encounters, no respites or times to really admire the rather beautiful scenery, or just take in the sounds of the world. The game is just poorly balanced combat- and the difficulty settings hardly seem to work. I know the difficulty is the only thing I'm talking about, but it honestly is just that bad.If you want to learn how not to balance a game, or see what you can really do with the source Hammer editor, then I'd really suggest giving it a shot. Otherwise, just look at the screenshots section. I do have to repeat that it is a really pretty game, and that if you are an aspiring source mapper, then you should spend the two hours with it.

												So, this game was suggested to me by a friend and he said it adds more to the Half-Life 2 storyline. I played about 60 minutes of this game...And I never want to play it again. Yes I know it's not exactly enough to make a review but in that small amount of time I already hate this game with all my heart. But hey! I'm going to give it credit for breaking the rage quit record in my playthrough history (right next to Mass Effect 3.)Gameplay: it's pretty much the same as Half-Life 2, no new content added...Well, except for the fact that you're instantly thrown into the game with useless weapons! no sneaking, no strategy like Half-Life 2 demanded. No, instead it just throws you on the island with about 3-4 gunners spamming grenades and killing you almost instantly before you know what happened to you. The A.I however is what I'm♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about. It feels somehow...altered, some of the actions the A.I commits is out of character. As for why the A.I has been altered I'm not entirely sure, my main assumption is to fit the mod creator's sported preferences. Either way this game is pretty much a free stress test on your mind. Also I should probably mention that the mobs have infinite spawn so good luck trying to create yourself some time to process what you're doing.The Story: You play as Gordon Freeman, you have been supposedly "saved" from the Combine. Your goal: kill everything and listen to a smartass over the comm channel. This is obviously poorly written fan fiction-- now of course you may just say "Peter, don't be harsh! everyone has their version of the story" you have no idea how long I've been reading this excuse someone out there counts as a storyline."Pip pip cheero good man! I am your Athena! you are my ♥♥♥♥♥ perseus! and this island is Medusa! would you be a dear and kill every moving thing while listenning to me as I explain everything to you in a swimming fancy way? Oh joy! allow me to show off my intelligence by saying words your tiny mind would have no understanding! Dulce et decorum est pro terra mori! I feel so smarter than you right now! teehee" This story has no connection at all with Half-life 2 so don't even bother trying to find a place to tuck it in the current universe (that's the mistake I made with Half-life: Before.) Now do you understand why I hate fanfiction? you want to write it? fine, but please don't turn it into a physical thing that has the potential to punch someone in the gutt...Potentially me that is.Final verdict: I'm giving this mod a 0/10. It has done nothing in any way to impress me or surprise me except chuck 50 bots at me then give me this prick I have to read as a reward! It's like spending hours slaying a dragon for the princess but instead all you get is a picture of the princess you were saving as a reward. I know there isn't a whole lot you can do without a large developement team but this was sad beyond words, and painful to just pay any serious amount of attention too.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Using only assets and mechanics from Half-Life 2 and its episodes - minus a few minors additions -, MINERVA still manages to deliver a gaming experience far different from Valve's game.From the nagging text monologues of the titular Minerva, strongly reminescent of System Shock's SHODAN and Marathon's Durandal, to the eldritch-ness, vastness and level of detail of the underground structure, the ambience is tense, cryptic and sometimes contemplative. The game is also challenging, both in its riddles and its combat, thanks to its unusual level design.Indeed, what really sets this mods apart from its progenitor, and from most FPS, is its level design. Instead of providing the player a world, Adam Foster provided his world a player. Don't expect strategically located chest-high walls, or conveniently located ammo crates. Every element is placed somewhere it would belong if the Combine's installation was a real-world place and not a videogame level. You will therefore often find yourself back-tracking or realizing several ways lead to the same location.This mod is truly a gem of game design and videoludic storytelling - no wonder its creator was hired by Valve afterwards.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Using only assets and mechanics from Half-Life 2 and its episodes - minus a few minors additions -, MINERVA still manages to deliver a gaming experience far different from Valve's game.From the nagging text monologues of the titular Minerva, strongly reminescent of System Shock's SHODAN and Marathon's Durandal, to the eldritch-ness, vastness and level of detail of the underground structure, the ambience is tense, cryptic and sometimes contemplative. The game is also challenging, both in its riddles and its combat, thanks to its unusual level design.Indeed, what really sets this mods apart from its progenitor, and from most FPS, is its level design. Instead of providing the player a world, Adam Foster provided his world a player. Don't expect strategically located chest-high walls, or conveniently located ammo crates. Every element is placed somewhere it would belong if the Combine's installation was a real-world place and not a videogame level. You will therefore often find yourself back-tracking or realizing several ways lead to the same location.This mod is truly a gem of game design and videoludic storytelling - no wonder its creator was hired by Valve afterwards.
